oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tongue Depressors and Cotton Swabs in Cylinder
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On cover of cylinder: ''Sklar Chrome USA''; on tongue depressors covers: ''Lozilles Throthricin - Propesin Longes''

A chrome cylinder that is divided into three sections. In the largest section are two tongue depressers in wrappers. The tongue depressers are coated with an anaesthetic to numb throat pain. In the other sections are sticks and cotton for making cotton swabs. The materials belonged to Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) who was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: AeroHalor in Box
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Abbott Laboratories
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
Becton-Dickinson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On the largest piece of the AeroHalor: ''Abbott, Patent Pending, Abbott Laboratories, North Chicago, Ill., U.S.A.'' On the top of the box: ''One set AeroHalor, Trade Mark (Abbott's Powder Inhaler), List No. 3785, 563557, For use with Abbott Sifter Cartridges, See directions for use in enclosed circular, patent applied for''

Three pieces of an AeroHalor (a dry powder inhaler) used by Dr. Arthur L. Esserman, a pediatrician in Denver, Colorado. The AeroHalor was made by Abbot Laboratories in Chicago, Illinois. Dry powder inhalers were used in the 1940s, primarily for aerosolizing penicillin. Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (AeroHalor in box), 7 x 9 x 4 centimeters
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Doctor's Leather Case With ENT Set
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On top of case: ''Arthur L. Esserman, M. D.''

Black leather rectangular case with metal clasp on outside. The top is personalized with the owner's name embossed in gold: ''Arthur L. Esserman, M.D.'' The inside has a plum colored velvet inner lining and three inner sections. The case is filled with pieces from a diagnostic ear, nose and throat (ENT) set. This case belonged to Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) who was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 to 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hypodermic Syringe In Box
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Becton-Dickinson
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medical instruments and apparatus
Jews
Medicine
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
Becton-Dickinson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On the syringe are markings up to 2 cubic-centimeters and reads: ''B-D Yale, Becton, Dickinson & Co.'' in red letters. On the top of the box: ''One 2cc., B-D Yale Luer-lok Hypodermic Syringe, Graduated: 1/10 cc. and Minims, No. 2YL, Becton, Dickinson & Co., Rutherford, N.J., Made in U.S.A., B-D Yale & Luer-Lok T.M. Reg. U. S. Pat. Off., Pat No. 1,998,982.''

A glass 2 cubic-centimeter B-D Yale Luer-Lok hypodermic syringe in a box used by Dr. Arthur L. Esserman, a pediatrician in Denver, Colorado. The Luer-Lok syringe was patented by Becton, Dickenson & Co. in 1925 in Rutherford, New Jersey; this locking syringe system is still in use. Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (syringe in box), 4 x 10 x 3 centimeters
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Medical bag
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraved metal plate on top of bag: ''Patent No. 1985521, Emdee by Schell.''

A black leather case with two leather handles and a metal clasp at the top. The interior sides of the case each have a compartment that close with a metal button. The flat opening case was patented by the Schell Co. in December of 1934. It was used by Dr. Arthur L. Esserman, a pediatrician in Denver, Colorado. Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A black leather case with zipper on one side. The inside has a leather band for holding syringes in place. Belonged to Dr. Arthur L. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On top of case: ''Arthur L. Esserman, M. D.''

Black leather rectangular case with metal clasp on outside. The top is personalized with the owner's name embossed in gold: ''Arthur L. Esserman, M.D.'' The inside has purple velvet lining and four inner sections. This case belonged to Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) who was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 to 1952.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stethoscope
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. P. Pilling & Son Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
G. P. Pilling & Son Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On the back of the circular piece: ''G P Pilling & Son Co., Philadelphia, Pat 1832422''

Stethoscope used by Dr. Arthur L. Esserman, a pediatrician in Denver, Colorado. Stethoscope consisting of two silver colored metal ear pieces with black rubber ends and rubber tubing attached to other side of metal pieces. They both attach to a V-shaped piece of silver metal with a piece of red rubber at the end. Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reflex Hammer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On handle: ''Adams''

A Taylor diagnostic reflex hammer, used by Dr. Arthur Esserman, has a steel handle and a triangular piece of rubber held in place by a steel loop at the end of the handle. James Madison Taylor designed the ''tomahawk'' reflex hammer in 1888. Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fractionally Distilled Water
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cutter Laboratories
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
Cutter Laboratories
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In raised lettering on bottle: ''- 100'' on side, ''Cutter Laboratories, 1A'' on bottom of glass. Printed on label: ''Fractionally Distilled Water, S-0506B, 100 cc, Sterile, Pyrogen-free, Safety Tested, For Professional Use Only, Made in U.S.A., Cutter Laboratories, Berkeley Calif. USA, Established 1897''. Cutter Laboratories logo on bottom of glass and on label.

Fractionally distilled water in a glass bottle with a rubber stopper holding 100 cubic centimeters. The water was for irrigation of wounds and boils. The bottle and water belonged to Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) who was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ENT Battery Case
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In raised lettering on top of case: ''Welch Allyn Co., Auburn, N.Y.''

A metal case for a battery used to provide light as part of an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) diagnostic kit. (The battery was removed because of safety concerns.) The ENT diagnostic kit belonged to Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) who was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 until his death in 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Glass and Metal Physician's Seal
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cut out in metal: ''73346''

A physician's seal made of metal and stained glass designed to attach to a hospital or medical building. There is a circular metal plate with a metal strip with a wing nut for attachment on the back side. On the outside circle of the seal are eight alternating pieces of green and white glass attached to the metal plate. On the interior circle striped red glass with a metal design of the rod of Asclepius and the letters M and D. The seal belonged to Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) who was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 until his death in 1952. Dr. Esserman initiated one of Denver's first medical buildings.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leather Business Card Case
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On top of case: ''Dr. A. Esseman [sic]''; inscribed: ''cards'' and ''perscriptions''

A dark brown leather case with gold embossing on right bottom corner: ''Dr. A. Esseman [sic]''. The left hand side has two flaps, the smaller section has ''Cards'' and the larger section has ''Prescriptions'' embossed in gold. Inside the case was a document titled: ''Recommendations for the care of the premature infant,'' dated October 1948. Belonged to Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) who was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 to 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Arthur L. Esserman, M.D. Medical Equipment and Papers, Medical Equipment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright restrictions may apply. User is responsible for all copyright compliance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leather Notebook With Symptoms and Treatments
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine
Jews
Medical instruments and apparatus
Esserman, Arthur,--1898-1952
Notebooks
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten label on interior reads: ''A.L. Esserman; 1595 Gilpin; Denver, COLO.''

A black leather notebook with six metal rings inside having an appearance of an address book, but used as a way to categorize symptoms and medical treatments. The back cover has flap and several medical charts and treatments are inside. There is a handwritten label inside: ''A.L. Esserman; 1595 Gilpin; Denver, COLO.'' Dr. Arthur L. Esserman (born 1898) was an intern at Children's Hospital in Denver, Colorado from 1924 to 1926 and practiced pediatric medicine in Denver from 1926 to 1952.
Title supplied by archivist.
